questions.text: A 29-year-old female presents with symptoms including fever, myalgia, and periorbital swelling. She mentions consuming undercooked pork during a recent camping trip. On physical examination, she exhibits noticeable edema around the eyes, tenderness in the muscles, and a palpable rash. Which diagnostic test is the most definitive for confirming the suspected condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Stool examination for ova and parasites

questions.text: Identify the correct feature of the given group of organisms.

options.label: A
options.text: They have a complete alimentary canal

questions.explanation:
Cestodes

Trematodes

Nematodes

These are long and segmented worms.

These are leaf-like and unsegmented.

These are elongated unsegmented worms.

They are dorsoventrally flattened and have no body cavity. (Option D)

These are also flatworms without a body cavity.

These are cylindrical worms and have a body cavity with well-differentiated organs.

They have no alimentary canal. (Option A)

They have an incomplete alimentary canal without an anus.

They have a complete alimentary canal.
  • They have suckers for attaching to the host.
  • Some have hooks as well. (Option B)
  • Suckers are present.
  • Hooks are absent.

Hooks and suckers are absent.

These are hermaphrodites (monoecious) (Option C)

Hermaphrodites except Schistosoma.

The sexes are separate (diecious)

Examples:

  • Diphyllobothrium
  • Taenia saginata
  • Taenia solium
  • Echinococcus granulosus
  • Hymenolepis nana
  • Dipylidium caninum

Examples:

  • Intestinal flukes:
    • Fasciolopsis buski
  • Blood flukes:
    • Schistosoma mansoni

Examples:

  • Small intestinal nematodes:
    • Ascaris
    • Hookworm
    • Strongyloides
  • Large intestinal:
    • Trichuris
    • Enterobius

questions.text: Match the following cestodes with the right features. Organism Features i) Taenia solium a. 4 suckers, no hooks ii) Taenia saginata b. 4 suckers, single row of 20-30 hooks iii) Hymenolopis nana c. 2 suctorial grooves or bothria, no suckers, no hooks iv) Diphyllobothrium latum d. 4 suckers, 2 rows of hooks
questions.explanation:
Morphology of cestodes

  • Cestodes are dorsoventrally flat and segmented intestinal worms that may vary in size from a few millimetres to several meters.
  • They are made of three parts:
    • Head or scolex
    • Neck
    • Trunk

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with gastrointestinal symptoms after consuming poorly cooked meat. A stool examination reveals the presence of eggs or gravid proglottids, suggesting a diagnosis of taeniasis. Which of the following statements regarding the causative agents of this infection is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: The eggs of Taenia saginata are infective to humans

options.label: B
options.text: The infective stage of Taenia saginata is Cysticercus bovis

options.label: C
options.text: The eggs of Taenia solium are not infective to humans.

options.label: D
options.text: Taenia solium is acquired through poorly cooked beef

questions.correct_answer: B. The infective stage of Taenia saginata is Cysticercus bovis
questions.explanation:
Taenia Species

T. saginata

T.solium

Definitive Host

Man

Man

Intermediate Host

Cattle (cow or buffalo)

Pig

Larva

Cysticercus bovis; present in cow not in man

Cysticercus cellulosae; present in pig and also in man

Egg

Not infective to man (Option A)

Infective to man (Option C)

Mode of Infection

Ingestion of the larval stage in poorly cooked cattle (cow or buffalo) meat.

Ingestion of the larval stage in poorly cooked pig meat. (Option D)

Diagnostic Form

Eggs or gravid proglottids in feces

Infective Form

Cysticercus bovis (Option B)

Cysticercus cellulosae

questions.text: A 39-year-old male presents with abdominal pain and a palpable abdominal mass. Ultrasound imaging shows findings depicted in the accompanying image. Based on the WHO classification of hydatid cysts, to which stage does this cyst correspond?
questions.explanation:

Cyst Type

Ultrasound Findings

CL

Unilocular Cyst

Cystic lesion and no visible cyst wall

CE1 (Option A)

Simple Active Cyst

CE2 (Option B)

Multivesicular Cyst

Honeycomb appearance: Visible cyst wall and internal septations

questions.text: An egg was extracted and observed under the microscope. Which of the following species does it belong to?
questions.explanation:
Hymenolepis nana (Dwarf Tapeworm)

Hymenolepis nana, or dwarf tapeworm, is a parasitic cestode primarily infecting humans and rodents, commonly causing infection in children.

It can complete its life cycle in a single host without requiring an intermediate host.

Morphology
  • Adult Worm: Measures 15–40 mm in length; features a scolex with four suckers and a retractable rostellum with hooks for attachment to the intestinal wall.
  • Proglottids: Segmented body, with each segment containing both male and female reproductive organs.

Life Cycle
  • Infective Stage: Eggs are excreted in feces and can survive in the environment.
  • Autoinfection: Ingested eggs hatch in the intestine, allowing direct development into adults, leading to reinfection.
  • Ingestion: Humans acquire infection by consuming contaminated food or water. Rodents can also act as hosts.
  • Larval Development: Oncospheres hatch in the intestine, penetrate intestinal villi, and develop into cysticercoids.
  • Maturation: Cysticercoids mature into adults in about 20–30 days, attaching to the intestinal wall and producing eggs.

Clinical features
  • Asymptomatic in many cases.
  • Symptomatic individuals may experience:
    • Abdominal pain and cramps
    • Diarrhea or loose stools
    • Loss of appetite and weight loss
    • Irritability (especially in children)
    • Nausea and vomiting (less common)

Investigations
  • Stool Examination: Microscopic detection of eggs using methods like Kato-Katz or concentration techniques.
  • PCR: Used for specific identification of H. nana DNA in stool samples.

Management

Antiparasitic Medication:

  • Praziquantel: First-line treatment, typically a single oral dose of 25 mg/kg.
  • Alternative: Nitazoxanide.

Features

Taenia Species

Diphyllobothrium latum

Hymenolepis nana

Hymenolepis diminuta

Egg Appearance

Brownish/yellow-brown, thick-shelled

Yellow-brown, operculated


 

Colourless to yellow-brown, thin-shelled



 

Similar to H. nana, slightly larger



 

Size (Diameter)

30-43 µm

50-76 µm

30-45 µm

40-70 µm

Shape

Spherical/ovoid

Ellipsoidal

Oval to Spherical

Oval to Spherical

Shell Characteristics

Striated (thick)

Operculum at one end, thin shell

Smooth, no striations

Smooth, no striations

Bile Staining

Negative

Positive

Negative

Negative

Other Features

Contains hooks in the larval stage (cysticercus); no hooks in T. saginata

Terminal knob at the opposite end

Contains polar filaments

Polar filaments, typically absent

Embryo Development

Cysticercus larva can develop within the host

Proglottids shed in water, release eggs

Can develop into an adult in a single host.

Requires an intermediate host (usually rodents)

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with abdominal pain and diarrhea. A stool sample is analyzed, revealing the presence of eggs that are oval in shape, have a smooth outer surface, and lack an operculum similar to the image given below. Given these findings, which of the following treatments is the most appropriate for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Hymenolepis diminuta

Hymenolepis diminuta, or rat tapeworm, is a parasitic tapeworm that primarily infects rodents but can occasionally infect humans through ingestion of infected insects.

Morphology

Adult Worm:

Large (20-60 cm) and slender, with a scolex that lacks hooks and has four suckers for attachment. Composed of many proglottids with both male and female organs.

Egg:

 
  • Eggs of H. diminuta are slightly oval, larger than those of H. nana, measuring around 60-80 µm in diameter.
  • They have a thick outer shell, a yellowish color, and lack polar filaments (distinguishing them from H. nana eggs).
  • Inside, there is an oncosphere (embryo) with six hooks that will aid in initial attachment upon ingestion by the insect host.

Life Cycle
  • Intermediate Host (Insects): Eggs ingested by insects (e.g., beetles, fleas) develop into cysticercoid larvae.
  • Definitive Host (Rodent/Human): Infection occurs when an insect with cysticercoid larvae is ingested. The larvae develop into adults in the host’s small intestine.
  • Human Accidental Host: Humans are infected through accidental ingestion of infected insects; direct human-to-human transmission is rare.

Clinical Features

Asymptomatic: Many human infections are asymptomatic, especially when there is a low parasite load.

 

Symptoms (in heavy infections): Abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and occasional weight loss.

Investigations
  • Stool Microscopy: Key diagnostic tool that reveals characteristic eggs that lack polar filaments.
  • Serology/PCR: Molecular confirmation in research or doubtful cases.

Management

Anthelmintics: Praziquantel (preferred) - single dose.

Laboratory tests reveal eggs with a characteristic terminal spine in the urine. Which of the following is a potential complication of this condition?

options.label: C
options.text: Squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder

questions.correct_answer: C. Squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder

  • Portal hypertension and periportal fibrosis.
  • Severe swimmer’s itch

  • Lung involvement: Cor pulmonale,pulmonary hypertension.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with complaints of abdominal pain, diarrhea, and significant weight loss over the past month. He recently traveled to a rural area where he ingested aquatic plants while swimming in a freshwater lake. On examination, he exhibits pallor and mild abdominal tenderness. A stool examination reveals the presence of eggs. Considering his symptoms and recent travel history, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Parasite

Fasciolopsis buski (Giant Intestinal Fluke) is a parasitic trematode infecting the small intestine of humans and pigs, causing fasciolopsiasis, leading to gastrointestinal symptoms and malabsorption.

Morphology

Adult:

  • Size: 20-75 mm in length.
  • Color: Brownish or yellowish.
  • Structure: Characteristic oral sucker at the anterior end for attachment; ventral sucker further down aids in feeding.
 

 

Egg:

  • Size: 130-140 micrometres in length, 80-85 micrometres in width.
  • Shape: Elliptical or oval.
  • Operculum: Possesses a lid-like structure at one end that opens when the egg is ready to release larvae.


 

Life Cycle
  1. Egg Stage: Eggs released in feces of infected humans or pigs, reach freshwater sources.
  2. Miracidium Stage: Eggs hatch into miracidia in water, which seek freshwater snails.
  3. Developmental Stages in Snail: Miracidia transform into sporocysts, rediae, and then cercariae.
  4. Metacercaria Stage: Cercariae encyst on aquatic plants, becoming metacercariae, infective to humans.
  5. Infection of Hosts: Humans/pigs ingest raw or undercooked aquatic plants with metacercariae.
  6. Adult Development: Metacercariae excyst in the small intestine, mature into adults, and lay eggs, completing the cycle.

Presentation Features

Acute Phase:

Symptoms appear 2-3 months after ingestion.

  • Abdominal Pain: Common, usually around the upper abdomen.
  • Diarrhea: Intermittent or prolonged.
  • Nausea and Vomiting: Frequent in heavy infections.
  • Malabsorption and Nutritional Deficiencies: Severe cases lead to growth retardation and edema, especially in children.

 

Chronic Phase:

Prolonged infection causes chronic diarrhea, weakness, and malabsorption due to the large size of flukes.

 

Eosinophilia: Elevated eosinophil count common in parasitic infections.

Investigations

Stool Examination: Primary diagnostic tool for detecting large, operculated eggs in fecal samples.

Serologic Tests: ELISA and immunodiagnostic tests, though less commonly used in endemic areas.

Imaging: Ultrasound or CT scans to detect adult flukes in cases of heavy infection or suspected obstruction.

Management

Pharmacological Treatment:

Praziquantel: Drug of choice for treating fasciolopsiasis, with a dosage of 25 mg/kg in a single dose.

Alternative Treatment: Triclabendazole, also effective but not universally available.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with abdominal pain, diarrhea, and recent weight loss after consuming unwashed vegetables in a rural area. Upon examination, a diagnostic test reveals the presence of eggs in her stool. Which of the following best describes the egg shown below?

options.label: A
options.text: It floats in saturated salt solution

options.label: B
options.text: It does not float in saturated salt solution

options.label: C
options.text: It has translucent shell with three layers

options.label: D
options.text: It has a large unsegmented ovum with coarse lecithin granules

questions.correct_answer: B. It does not float in saturated salt solution
questions.explanation:
Laboratory diagnosis & Treatment of Ascaris lumbricoides

Stool Examination
  • Detects both fertilized & unfertilized eggs using saline and iodine wet mount.
  • If negative, concentration by sedimentation is recommended (floatation is ineffective as unfertilized eggs do not float).

Adult Worm Detection
  • Occasionally visible in stool or sputum. Barium X-ray may show worms in the intestine as "trolley car lines" if aligned in parallel.
  • Ultrasound or cholangiopancreatography helps detect worms in extraintestinal sites.

Larva Detection
  • During early pulmonary migration, larvae may appear in sputum or gastric aspirates before stool detection.

Serology
  • Antibody testing (e.g., ELISA) is sensitive but cannot distinguish recent from past infections and may cross-react with other helminths.

Molecular Methods
  • PCR can identify Ascaris in stool, and differentiate between Ascaris, Trichuris, and hookworm.
  • Real-time PCR quantifies parasite load.

Other Indicators
  • Eosinophilia is common in early lung stages.
  • Charcot-Leyden crystals may appear in sputum and stool.

Treatment
  • Albendazole: 400 mg as a single dose.
  • Mebendazole: 100 mg twice daily for 3 days or 500 mg as a single dose.

Unfertilized Egg

Fertilized Egg
  • It is Elliptical, narrow, & long
  • Size: 80 µm x 55 µm
  • Shell: Thin with an irregular albumin coating
  • Contents: Small, atrophied ovum with disorganized refractile granules
  • Does not Float in saturated salt solution. (Option B)
  • Round or oval in shape.
  • Size: 60-75 µm x 40-45 µm
  • Color: Golden brown, bile-stained
  • Shell: Thick, smooth, translucent with three layers
    • Outer: Coarsely mammillated albuminous coat
    • Middle: Thick transparent layer
    • Inner: Lipoidal vitelline membrane (Option C)
  • Decorticated Variant: Some eggs lack the outer mammillated coat.
  • Contents: Large unsegmented ovum with coarse lecithin granules, leaving clear areas at poles (Option D)
  • Floats in saturated salt solution. (Option A)

FERTILISED

UNFERTILISED

DECORTICATED

questions.text: A patient presents with abdominal pain and anorexia. She also complains of bloody diarrhea and generalized weakness. During stool examination, the following was observed: Which of the following drugs is the best choice for treatment?

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The presence of two ventral and two dorsal chitinous cutting plates in the adult worm

options.label: D
options.text: The head of the larva bends in the opposite direction to the curvature of the body

(New World)

Similar

Similar

Similar

Similar

Larger and thicker

Small and slender

Buccal capsule

4 ventral teeth and 2 dorsal knob-like teeth

2 ventral and 2 dorsal chitinous cutting plates (Option C)

Pathogenicity

More

Comparatively less

Caudal spine in female

Present

Absent

Filariform worms

The anterior end bends in the same direction as the curvature of the body (vs Option D)

The anterior end is bent in the opposite direction to the curvature of the body

Pulmonary reaction

More common (vs Option B)

Life span

2-7 years

questions.text: A male patient comes with complaints of rashes on the skin that appear as follows. He gives a history of walking barefoot in soil in the fields near his house. Which organism could be the most probable cause of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Cutaneous larva migrans
  • It is also known as the creeping eruption (also known as ground itch).
  • This condition is caused by an infection by a nematode larvae through skin penetration.

Etiology

Common causes:

  • Nonhuman hookworm species:
    • Ancylostoma braziliense
    • A. caninum

Pathogenesis

Lifecycle:

  • Parasite eggs are excreted in the feces of infected animals and hatch in soil.
  • Infection occurs when contaminated soil comes into contact with human skin.
  • Larvae penetrate the skin, causing infection, and migrate beneath the epidermis.

In human hosts:

  • Humans are accidental hosts; hence, the larvae cannot penetrate the deeper layers of the skin (basement membrane).
  • So, the disease remains confined to the outer skin layers.

Clinical features

Creeping eruptions:

  • Itchy papules develop into serpiginous tunnels in the epidermis.
  • The lesions shift with larval movements, leading to the name "creeping eruption."
  • Secondary bacterial infections may arise from scratching.

Transient creeping eruptions:

  • Occasionally caused by the human hookworm, Necator americanus.
  • Other conditions like gnathostomiasis and sparganosis may produce similar symptoms.
  • The lesions are deeper and subcutaneous or in the muscles.
  • Loeffler’s syndrome may develop in many cases.

Clinical diagnosis
  • Eosinophilia is rare and occurs primarily with Loeffler's syndrome.
  • Serological tests are not developed.
  • Larvae are rarely found on biopsy; hence, diagnosis relies on clinical features.

Treatment
  • Medications:
    • Thiabendazole is effective for treatment.
  • Lesion management:
    • Freezing the advancing part of the eruption with ethyl chloride is effective for localized lesions.

 

Cutaneous larva migrans

Visceral larva migrans

Definition

  • This is a serpiginous skin eruption due to burrowing larvae of animal hookworms.
  • It is caused by non-human nematodes that are unable to develop in human hosts and instead migrate through tissues as larvae.
  • The migration of the larvae through the skin causes an eosinophilic inflammation.

Tissue involved

It involves the skin

Involves various organs of the body like the liver, lungs, and eyes.

Infecting organisms

Mostly by non-human hookworms like

  • A.caninum
  • A.braziliense
  • Uncinaria stenocephala
  • Bunostomum phlebotomum

Mainly by dog and cat roundworms like

  • Toxocara canis (Option D)
  • Toxocara cati
  • Ascaris suum (Option B)
  • Angiostrongylus cantonensis
  • Gnathostoma spinigerum (Option A)
  • Anisakis simplex
  • Baylisascaris procyonis

Portal of entry

Penetration of the skin by larva

Ingestion of infected eggs

Eosinophilia

Mild

Persistent high

Serodiagnosis

Not developed

Well developed

Treatment

Thiabendazole

Diethylcarbamazine and prednisolone
